div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Rumored landing of Yankees at Newport News.
div3.p:
Information reached some of our advanced forces stationed on the Williamsburg road, on Sunday night, that the Abolitionists were landing in large numbers at Newport News.
If the information be correct, it is not improbable that the Yankees alluded to comprise the army corps of Gen. Smith, that sailed from Fortress Monroe last Thursday.

div3.head: The Florida still Afloat.
div3.p: From a private letter just received per steamer Ruby, from a gentleman of high respectability at Nassau, on his way to Europe, and dated February 10th, we are permitted to make the following extract:

q.p:
It was the Alabama that sunk the Hatteras.
The Florida has also sent the Annie to the bottom.

bibl.n: A gentleman of high respectability at Nassas

div3.p: P. S.--Pardon extreme haste to catch the Ruby.

div3.head: Gen. Steeling price.
div3.p: The Jackson (Miss.) Crisis states that a telegram received there announces that a new appointment has been made for Gen. Holmes's destrier, and that Major-Gen. Price will be placed in the active command of all the troops in that department, taking with him the Missouri regiments now in the Army of the West.

div3.head: Large Fires in Norfolk and ports South.
div3.p:
Passengers who left Norfolk on the 10th inst. state that there was a large fire in that city just previous to their departure.
It broke out in the store formerly occupied by Bloodgood & Co., and extended along Main street to Market square, and thence down the square to Butt & Douglas's shoe store.
Same fifteen large buildings were entirely consumed.
The fire was supposed to be accidental.
The following is a list of the houses destroyed in Norfolk: Kerr's china store, Hoffheimer's clothing store, T J Cornick's drug store, E P Tabb's hard, ware store, T F Owen's dry goods store, Gorauch's dry goods store, J D Reed's bat store, R H Stevers's hat store, L L Brickhouse's boot and shoe store, Wm H Millar's dry goods store, Seabury Sons' boot and shoe store, T Baltimore's boot and shoe store, H J Griffith's hardware store.
T B Reardan's grocery store, and Butt & Douglaz's shoe store.
The value of the buildings destroyed is estimated at $150,030. They, for the most part, belonged to the estate of Geo, Newton, dec'd.
In Portsmouth, a fire had destroyed all the buildings on the North side of London street, from Court to Middle streets, except the Presbyterian Church.

Great excitement was created in the city when it was rumored that Gen. Pryor was on his way to attack Norfolk.
Two large steamers were brought up and anchored between Norfolk and Portsmouth, with the determination to destroy the two cities in case the attack was made.

div3.head:
Napoleon's plan of Mediation.
the Inside correspondence between Seward and Dayton.
div3.p:
The New York Herald, of the 13th instant, contains an important correspondence between the French Minister of Foreign Affairs and Mr. Dayton, the Yankee representative at the French Court and Seward, Lincoln's Minister of State.--This correspondence opens with a letter from Dayton to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, M. Drocyn D'Lhuys in response to some questions previously asked in relation to the population of the Southern States and the position of the several divisions of the Northern army.
In it the writer attempts to contract the position of affairs at the time the letter was written (Nov. 17, 1862.) with that of one year previous, and argues that the advance of the Union forces late the factory of the South has been gradual since the commencement of the war. Upon this subject he says: "In a word the insurgents do not now hold a foot of ground which they did not hold early in the war, while the flag of the Union has been constantly advancing and now floats somewhere on the soil or over the fortifications of every slave State save one.
Their armies have, in the meantime, been driven from an area of country embracing in the aggregate not less than 100,000 square miles, and occupied by a population ranging from 1,500,000 to 2,000,000 of people."

The writer then alludes to the relative naval strength of the two sections, and says that while all the incipient efforts on the part of the South to create a navy have been defeated, and her vessels destroyed, the navy of the United States has, within the year, grown from a comparatively small to a very great power, closing all the ports of the South, precluding, save with Federal consent, all entrance to or exit from them unless by stealth or accident.
Two other elements of relative strength for the continuation of the war are considered in the letter, viz: man and money.
Mr. Dayton says the armies of the South have been large beyond example compared with the extent of population from which they have been drawn, and informs the French Minister that to raise them to the present standard the conscription law has embraced all between the ages of eighteen and forty-five, and thinks there can be little force in reserve to supply the drain consequent upon the casualties of war. To corroborate this view, the French Minister is referred to the census statistics of 1860.

Alluding to the emancipation proclamation of Lincoln, issued in September, Dayton says: "Whoever may have entertained apprehensions of a servile war, such I do not suppose for a moment to have been contemplated by the President in foreshadowing his policy." The allusion to this proclamation is made to show that slaves hitherto have been an element of strength rather than of weakness to the South in the pending war.

Passing from the question of population, Mr. Dayton proceeds to the consideration of the relative monetary element of strength in war of the two sections.
He has arrived at the conclusion that while the resources of the South in men are practically exhausted, its resources in money must be equally so. He says that he is instructed that the South, with a floating debt of $100,000,009 represented by paper at a discount of 75 per cent, have neither raised, nor have the means of raising, a revenue equal to $10,000,000, in any form or for any purpose.
On the other hand, he is instructed that the Government of the United States has a revenue available in the precious metals of more than $100,000,000, while its mines are yielding gold more rapidly than foreign trade withdraws it from the country.
He concludes by saying that equality has existed nowhere, except on certain battle-fields in Virginia, between the two great armies.
He does not seem to depreciate the gallantry of Southern soldiers, regarding there as still his countrymen.

In reply to this letter the French Minister says that the information communicated, and the suggestions threw out, are certainly of a nature to make him appreciate all the resources of the Federal Government, and adds, "but it is none the less true, that notwithstanding the inequality of numbers and of financial means, notwithstanding local advantages and partial conquests, the conditions of toil and climate seem to oppose insuperable obstacles to the progress of the struggle, and that the equal energy of both sides tends to impress upon it a character of indeniable desperation." He is prepared to render homage to the courage which the Americans, upon the one side and the other, have shown thus far, but says that this courage, even while it excited the admiration of the world, is only calculated to render more uncertain the result of the combat, and to the of the disaster of this bloody war. He then refers to the feelings which the has given rise to in the French and step profound sympathy for America has inspired in the Government of the Emperor, in the hope of opening a way to reconciliation. "

This step, in the opinion of the Emperor, ought and could only be taken with the consent and concurrence of the two belligerent parties.
He stated that the reception given to the French proposition by the Cabinate of London and St. Petersburg.
prevents its being pashed further for the present.
The letter concludes by saying, "that if some day the Americans, tired of turning their valor against themselves, should wish to have recourse to us, in order to seek in concert the mean of forminating this conflict they would find us always ready, associated with other powers or separately, to aid them with our co- operation, and to testify by our good offices the feelings which have not ceased to animals France in regard to them.
This letter bears date of the 23½ of November, 1862.

The next, in the series of letters embraced in this correspondence, are three several communications from Seward to Dayton.
In the first of those he says, "it is proper for me to say that neither M. Mereler nor any other person has had the least warrant from any authority of the United States for representing to his Government that the President would be disposed to entertain any preposition in regard to the action of his Government in the conduct of our domestic affairs from any foreign quarter whatsoever.
The exact contrary is in effect all that has ever passed between all the ministers residing here and this department." This letter is date Nov. 23, 1862.

The second letter of Seward, under date of Nov. 30 repeats that the United States have continually said to all Europe that they know that the saving of the American Union depends on the American people, and not at all on the policies of foreign States, severally or combined.
Foreign nations, he thinks need scarcely to be reminded that family quarrels are always of short duration; that the very scandel which they bring operates as an incentive to reconciliation.
His next letter is dated on the 11th of December, and merely acknowledges the reception of the correspondence between Dayton and the French Minister of Foreign Affairs.

The next letter of importance in the correspondence in one bearing date the 15th of January, 1863, from Dayton to Seward, informing him that a dispatch would shortly be sent by M. Drouyn de L'huys to M Mereler, requesting him to suggest, on a suitable occasion, the propriety of appointing commissioners to treat with the South for peace and for Union, if possible; if not possible, for such terms of separation as may be eventually agreed upon.
This communication was submitted by Dr. toyn de L'huys to the Emperor on the 9th; and returned by him on the 14th.
It contains the following propositions:
First--No interferences of any kind by a foreign power.

Second.--It does not require or ask for any cessation of hostilities pending the negotiations; but, like the negotiations for peace in 1783, between the United States and Great Britain, permits everything to proceed as if no efforts for a settlement were being made.

Then follows the communication of the French Minister of Foreign Affairs to M. Mercier.
The Minister says. "The little success of our overtures might chill the interest with which we follow the fluctuations of this contest; but the sentiment to which we have yielded is too since for indifference to find a place in our thoughts, that we should cease to be painfully affected while the war continues to rage." He says that the French Government is none the less ready amid the wishes formed in favor of peace, to take into account all the susceptibilities of national feeling; and does not at all question the right of the Federal Government to decline the co-operation of the great maritime powers of Europe, but asks whether this co-operation is not the only means which offers itself to the Cabinet at Washington to hasten the close of the war; and further, if the Federal Government believes that it ought to repel any foreign intervention, could it not honorably accept the idea of direct informal conferences with the authority which may represent the States of the South?
He says that the opening of informal conferences between the belligerent parties does not necessarily imply the immediate cessation of hostilities.
He then proceeds: "That nothing, therefore, would hinder the Government of the United States, without renouncing the advantage which it believes it can attain by the continuation of the war, from entering upon informal conferences with the Confederates of the South, in case they should show themselves disposed thereto.
Representatives or commissioners of the two parties could assemble at such point as it should be deemed proper to designate, and which could for this purpose be deemed neutral.
Reciprocal complains would be examined into at this meeting." A negotiation of this of the objections raised against the to intervention of Europe, and, without giving birth to the same hopes as the immediate conclusion of an armistice would exercise a happy influence on the march of events.

Seward in a lengthy letter to Dayton, under date of the 5th of February, acknowledges the report of the dispatch of the French Minister.
In its conclusion, he says that the Congress of the U. States furnishes a constitutional forum for debates between the alienated parties, and that Senators and Representatives from the loyal people are there already, fully empowered to confer; and says that seats are all of vacant inviting the Senators and Representatives of the discontented party, who may be constitutionally sent there from the States involved in the insurrection.
He thinks that the conferences which can thus be held in Congress have a great advantage over any that could be organized on the plan suggested by the French Minister, viz: that Congress, if it thought wise could call a National Convention to adopt its recommendations and give them all the solemnity and binding force of organic law. Such conferences he says, may be said to have already begun; that Maryland, Virginia Kentucky, Tennessee, and Missouri, States claimed by the insurgents, are already represented in Congress, and are submitting, with perfect freedom and a proper spirit, their advice upon the course best calculated to bring about, in the shortest time, a firm, lasting, and honorable peace.
This dispatch he authorizes Mr. Dayton to read to the French Minister, and to give him a copy if he shall desire it.

div3.head: Progress of the war.
div3.p:
We have received from our own correspondent at Fredericksburg, the New York Herald and Philadelphia Inquirer, of the 13th inst. The news contained in them is not important.
We give below a summary of the intelligence:

div4.head: The Yankee troops at the Blackwater fight.
div4.p:
It is stated that the Yankee troops before the fight at Blackwater were so much demoralized that when the fight commenced the field officers of one regiment refused to lead it in all. Had the Confederates pursued, instead of falling back, the Yankee writers think a rout would have resulted.
The following is an extract from the order of Gen. Peek, complimenting Corcoran and his troops after the fight:

q.p:
The misconduct of some of the troops has been brought to his notice.
But he forbears to specify them, in the belief that those conscious of deserving consure will avail themselves of the first opportunity to retrieve the past.

div4.head: The calling Cut of the "National"forces.
div4.p:
In the U. S. Senate, on the 9th last, a bill was reported from the Military Committee "for enrolling and calling out the national forces, and for other purposes." Section four provides that all citizens between the ages of eighteen and forty-five shall perform military duty when called upon by the President of the United States.
The examples are is follows: All such as are physically, mentally, or morally unfit for service; such as are necessary for the support of aged and infirm parents, orphans, or helpless children, and the only son of aged parents.
Where there are two sons of aged parents liable to do duty, the father or mother shall elect which of them shall serve; the other to be exempted.
The only brother of orphan children under twelve years of age, and all fathers having two or more children not over fourteen years of age, who may reside on a farm of not more than fifty acres, on which the are dependent for support, as also convicts and felons are exempted.
A bill was introduced to furnish additional troops, which provides that every able-bodied male between eighteen and forty-five years, of African descent, made free by the confliction act, or the emancipation proclamation shall be enrolled to serve during the war.--The number to be enrolled is not to exceed three hundred thousand man, and on their discharge the privates are to receive ten and the commissioned officers twenty five acres of land, to be located on the confiscated land of rebels.

div4.head: Tired of reading about the war.
div4.p:
It seems that even in some parts of New England the people have begun to be weary of so much political preaching.
A notable case is that of the "Old Congregational Society" of New Boston, Litchfield county, Conn, where Dr. Lyman Beecher so long preached.
This society, at a recent meeting, passed the following resolution:

Voted. That the Pulpit Committee of this society are hereby instructed that whenever they employ a Ministers of the Gospel to preach in their meeting he is employed to preach the General truth according to the Bible Moctrious, Carlit and him crucified, and that only. That he is strictly prohibited by a vote of this society from delivering any discourses of any description upon the present war, and that he shall not allude to the matter either in prayer or sermon.

div4.head: Speech of Hon, Henry may of Baltimore, in the Yankee Congress.
div4.p:
--peace resolutions.
Mr. May, of Baltimore, made a very able speech in the Yankee Congress against the whole policy of the Yankee Government, and in favor of peace and the immediate recognition of the Confederate States.
In the course of his remarks he said:

q.p:
Mr. Speaker, that eminent and far-seeing statesman, the late Judge Douglas, avowed to me in April proceding his death his solemn conviction that our political union was at an end. I violate no confidence in repeating his opinions, since he assured me it was his purpose to publish his views at an early day; and if the sequel of his life may seem in conflict with these views there are those among his personal friends here on this floor who can reconcile his conduct, and show the conformity of his plans with a peaceful though it might be a revolutionary solution of our national troubles.
Judge Dougles on that occasion read to me an esbay, that he told me had cost him more thought and labor than any work of his life; that he feared it was too long, and he wished both to abridge and simplify it, so that it might be read and understood by all; that he would revise it at Chicago, and then give it to his countrymen.--Death, this most patriotic design.

div4.p:
That essay ascribed our present situation to the aggressive spirit of Northern abolitionism.
It declared his conviction that the union of our States as originally formed and maintained was finally destroyed, and no political union could exist again between the free and slaveholding States; that such an idea must be abandoned, and a commercial union, founded upon the plan generally of the zoli verein of the States of Germany, he accepted as the only practicable arrangement to secure peace now and hereafter.
The masterly paper, every word of which I heard read by himself, and which since his death I have endeavored in vain to procure for the benefit of its wise course's to our countrymen, fully, explained the plan operation, and results of the zoli verein, and showed how, with certain modifications.
It could be adapted to sustain all those principal causes and influences which have hitherto made the United States the happiest and most prosperous of nations.
Mr. May concluded his speech by reading the following resolutions, which he intended to offer for adoption:

q.p: Whereas, The deplorable civil war now existing between the States heretofore composing our Union has failed to restore it, and if continued longer will destroy all hope of its restoration in the future, as originally formed and maintained by our Federal Constitution, and no other political Union is either desirable or practicable; and, whereas, the interests of humanity, of civilization, and the future of free constitutional Government, all concur in requiring that this dreadful contest of arms should be terminated: Therefore.

div4.p:
Be it Resolved, 1.
That it is the duty of Congress at once to appoint — commissioners to effect an armistice between the contending armies, and to secure peace at all events.

2. That said commissioners be empowered, by compromise, to restore the Union, if possible; but if not, then to arrange the terms of a peaceful separation from Union, as well of those States which now claim to have seceded, as of such others as, by the will of their people in sovereign conventions assembled may hereafter ordain to secede; and that said commissioners be solemnly enjoined so to conduct their negotiations as to secure, by every proper and honorable means, if practicable, a more harmonious and permanent reunion of all the States in a commercial if not a political system.

3. That said commissioners make a report of their transactions to Congress as soon as possible, in order that such legislation may be provided as may be necessary to assemble the people of the several States in convention to determine their action in the promises.

4. That in the event of a refusal by the Government of the United States to secure peace, and the only hopes of a reunion upon the terms and by the means herein provided, or by some other practicable plan, it is hereby recommended to the Governments of the several States new composing the Union at once to take measures to effect these objects.
The N. Y. Tribune, reviewing Mr. May's speech, says:

q.p: The Hon. Henry May, of Baltimore who is believed to be better acquainted with the feelings and purposes of the rebels than any other man in the House, is reported in the Globe to have said in his speech yesterday: "The people of the South believe, and I believe that there is established a fixed and unutterable antagonism between the sessions where slavery is and is not allowed, and that no future political union, as long as slavery exists, can ever be maintained between them upon any basis whatever."

div4.p: Mr. May went on to say that the only alternatives presented to the country are "separation or subjugation," and he administered a rebuke to Mr. Vallandigham for laying so much stress upon arguments for reunion found in physical geography, when all hopes of it were forbidden by reasons interest in the of man."
The New York Times, on the same subject, says:

q.p:
Some Republicans are so much outraged at Henry May's speech on Monday, (which he was permitted to print after delivering only a part of it,) that they talk of bringing in a resolution for his expulsion.
He said that the rebellion stood before the world justified of God and man, and that the war could only end in one or two ways — subjugation or separation — as restoration with slavery was now forever impossible.

div4.p: The Republicans also foolishly convented to let Wickliffe print a speech which he did not deliver; and now it is feared that it will expose equally bold treason when it appears.

div4.head: Horrible death of Confederate prisoners.
div4.p:
The death by freezing of twelve Confederate prisoners at Camp Douglas, Ohio, has been noticed.
The 65th Illinois (Scotch) regiment, on guard there, held a meeting and protested against the condition of the camp and barracks.
The Chicago Times has the following particulars of the death of the prisoners:

q.p:
Word was brought to the city last evening that during the night of Sunday, twelve of the Confederate prisoners confined in the pens at Camp Douglas were frozen to death.
It is asserted that on Monday morning they were found in the miserable handful of hay in their bunks frozen stiff, though to all appearances in the enjoyment of perfect health the day previous.
The barracks at Camp Douglas are well known to be totally unfitted during the prevalence of such weather as the present, for the use of anything, scarcely cattle.
These in which these prisoners are confined are many of them destitute of stoves; the windows in some of them are broken out, and through the holes and the cracks in the sides and the apertures in the roof the cold wind freely enters.

div4.p:
It is said that the local officers at the camp, actuated by a humanity their superiors might pattern after with profit, have done all in their power to make the condition of the prisoners comfortable.
But there are those above them who have a terribles in to answer for. It were mercy that, after their capitulation, our cannon had been turned upon these prisoners, and butch red them where they stood, than that from a far Southern clime, without any preparation being made for their comfort or protection they should be transported hither, to meet with scarcely anything worthy the name of shelter, the fierce rigors of a Northern winter-- to be murdered by neglect — to endure the tortures of a death by cold.

div4.head:
The attack on Fort Donelson--Confederate
account
div4.p:
The Confederate account of the attack on Fort Donelson almost entirely refutes the Yankee version of the affair.
We only had 800 men in the affair.
A letter from a soldier in Wheeler's cavalry says:

q.p:
At 3 o'clock P. M. on the 3d we came in the vicinity of Fort Donelson, and, upon inquiry, citizens informed us that the force was not very large, and had no fortifications; whereupon it was concluded to attack the point.
Accordingly General Forrest, with three or four hundred men on the right, and General Wharton, with about the same number on the left, commenced the fight, which lasted with much vigor for two or three hours--It was but the work of a moment to capture a part and drive the remainder of the several companies which were posted outside the fortifications — Right bravely did our boys move up to their work, Gen Forrest charging once on horseback and then again on foot; but so strongly entrenched were the Yankees in their fortifications and rifle pits that he retired, although he had succeeded in entering the streets of the town.
Gen. Wherton, with his command, had succeeded in getting into the town on the left, next to the river, after having captured quite a number of prisoners, small arms, and a very superior 12 pounder rifled piece, with its caisson, horses, and ammunition.
Thus we drove them into a small space; but from their rifle pits and windows of houses they poured a very heavy fire upon us, which, I am happy to say, was not very disastrous to us.

div4.p:
Night was upon us, and the broad silver moon gave as her cheering light by which to continue the attack — but finding our artillery ammunition nearly expended, and that of the small arms steadily decreasing, it was determined to retire.
Just then information reached us that reinforcements were coming from Fort Henry, and we distinctly heard the shouts of those who were coming up and down on the gunboats.
All these concurrent circumstances combined to induce us to retire.
Before our rear had left the old fortifications, the gunboats began a most furious shelling, which continued during nearly the entire night.
We would have been glad to have taken the garrison, but 1,200 men in rifle paid with a fine battery of artillery, was rather heavy for cavalry, but the exp resulted in the capture of nearly a hundred prisoners, among whom were five commissioned officers, a number of wagons, ambulances, small arms, and a fine brass rifled piece.

div4.head: Running the blockade.
div4.p: The King Philip arrived last evening from the lower Potomac, bringing & Cirgett and William Bayty, of this city, Rev. Mr. Newin, and Hyissopal Minister, an Englishman, a woman, and a colored man, who were taken on Saturday night by about of the schooner Dgu Smith, under of Summer, in Herring Creek, Mr. Mary's co., while attempting to land on the Maryland side.--This party together with Lord and Col. Lasils, of the British army, left Richmond in company, and were to cross at one the two last named took a smaller boat and in another place, making their escape.--Washington Star of Monday.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
The Evening Journal.--Mr. A. D. Bulleau has cavered his connection with the Philadelphia Evening Journal. It is not known who the publisher now is as no name has been in the place of Mr. Bulleau's. It is that Mr. Bulleau, in consequence of having signed the Parole given to General Schenck has been compelled to leave his paper.
Mr. D. A. Haboney, late of Iowa, but more lately of the Old Capital prison, has been mentioned as its editor.
A solemn requiem man was celebrated at the Cathedral in Nashville, on the 28th ult, for the repose of the souls killed on both sides as Murfreesboro'.
At a meeting of citizens of Orange to, N. Y., on the 7th instant, a resolution was offered to repudiate the $40,000 debt contracted in bounties for volunteers.
Com. Bell warns all vessels of the fact that he has re-established the Federal blockade at Galveston.
An attempt to arrest a deserter in Hadson city. N. J., last week, was resisted by this people, and the Provost forced to liberate his
The New Orleans Picayune of the states that Rio Grande advice of January that the French had not occupied Matament.
A resolution has been offered in the New York Legislature looking to the punishing as any refusal by officers to grant a writ of habeas corpus.
Hon. Nathan Hall, editor of the Boston Advertiser, died on the 10th inst.

Some negroes, coming out of Canterbury Hall (a theatrical place) in Washington city, on the 10th instant, were set upon by the whites and dreadfully beaten.
The police did not interfere.

Mrs. Beecher Stowe, in reply to an address from the women of England, some years ago, urging the abolition of slavery, writes that the great anti-slavery work to which their English sisters exhorted them is almost done.
--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock M., by Mr. Hunter, of Virginia, and opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Sehon, of Nashville, Tennessee.
Mr. Hunter, of Virginia, having resigned his position as a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Mr. Clark, of Missouri, was elected in his stead.
A communication was presented from C. H. Morrison, of Louisiana, praying the passage of a law allowing commutation of rations for sick troops in the field.
A bill was introduced making Columbia, S. C., a port of entry for goods imported into Charleston, S. C., and Wilmington, N. C., Read and referred.
Mr. Orr. of S. C., introduced a bill authorizing the discharge of certain civil officers from the military service of the Confederate States; which was read and referred.

Mr. Orr, of S. C., presented the petition of Jos. A. Yates, a citizen of South Carolina, praying to be allowed compensation for the appropriation by the officers of the Government of a patent granted to him for improved machinery for traversing guns Referred to the Military Committee.

Mr. Brown, of Miss., introduced a joint resolution declaring that hereafter it shall not be lawful for any C. S. Quartermaster not on duty with the army in the field, to issue or deliver any clothing, or cloth to be manufactured, or boots or shoes, to any person whatsoever, except upon the requisition of officers actually on duty in their proper stations or commands; and said fact must be certified by Colonels of regiments to which said officers are attached.
Such requisitions shall be approved by a general officer, etc. If any officer shall sell or dispose of any article to any person other than an officer on duty with our army in the field, he shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and on conviction thereof shall be discharged from office.

Mr. Dortch, of N. C., presented sundry resolutions passed by the Legislature of the State vindicating North Carolina from certain aspersions of persons in and out of the State.
Laid on the table and ordered to be printed.

On motion of Mr. Dortch, of N. C., a resolution was adopted to inquire into the expediency of amending and making more stringent the laws in regard to persons guilty of aiding and abetting or harboring deserters from the army.

Mr. Barnwell, of S. C., from the Finance Committee, reported back the bill in rela assistant Treasurers and Depositaries, with an amendment in the shape of a 5th section, which bill the committee recommend do pass.

Mr. Yancey, of Ala, introduced a bill authorizing the Secretary of the Navy to employ the best pilots for service in the Confederate Marine, on board of vessels used by the Confederate States in running the blockade, which was passed.

Mr. Semmas, of La., from the Judiciary Committee, reported back the bill to allow the Comptroller of the Treasury the privilege of obtaining the legal advice of the Attorney General, with the recommendation that it do not pass.

Mr. Hill, of Ga., from the Judiciary Committee, reported back adversely the bill amending the 10th section of an act to establish the Judicial Courts of the Confederate States; and the bid to amend the sequestration act, with an amendment, which bill was placed on the calender.

The bill providing for the impressment and appropriation of the action in the Confederate States coming up as the order of the day, the consideration thereof, on motion of Mr. Orr, was postponed until Tuesday.

The Senate resumed the consideration of the Senate bill to amend the Military Exemption Act of last session.
The pending question was on the motion of Mr. Phelan to lay the bill upon the table, with the view of taking up the House bill to repeal those clauses of the Exemption act relating to the police of plantations.

Mr. Yancey, of Ala, being entitled to the floor, addressed the Senate at length in opposition to the action proposed by the House.
He presented an elaborate argument in reputation of the prejudice excited against the said clauses of the Exemption act. He was followed on the other side by Mr. Phelan.
The vote being taken on laying the Senate bill on the table, resulted — ayes 7, noes 19.
The bill was then read by sections and amended.
At 4 o'clock the further consideration of the bill and amendments was postponed.

A message was announced from the President on the subject of the impressment made by the military authorities of property belonging to certain citizens of Lynchburg and Petersburg.
Printed.
Two communications on the subject of finance were read from the Secretary of the Treasury. --Printed.
Adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock.

Reports from Committees--Mr. Kenner, of La. from the Committee of Ways and Means, reported back Senate bill to authorize the issue of bonds for funding Treasury notes, with amendments, (which were adopted,) and the bill, as amended, was read a third time and passed.
The bill was immediately sent to the Senate for the concurrence of that body in the amendments proposed by the Committee of Ways and Means.

Mr. Kenner, from the same committee, reported back a bill, referred to the committee, to refund to the State of Alabama the amount overpaid by said State, on account of the war tax of 1862, with a recommendation that it do pass.
The bill was taken up and passed.

Mr. Kenner, from the same committee, also reported back a resolution of inquiry in relation to claims for arrearages of pay due to deceased soldiers, and asked that the committee be discharged from its consideration, on the ground that the subject did not pertain to the duties of that committee.
Mr. Goode, of Va., who offered the resolution, moved its reference to the Committee on Claims; which was agreed to.

Mr. Harris of Mo., from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back a bill for the relief of certain officers and soldiers from the State of Missouri.
The rules were suspended and the bill considered and passed.

Mr. Miles, of S. C., from the same committee, reported a bill in response to a resolution with reference to minors holding commissions in the army.--The bill provides that a minor may hold commission, unless in some position requiring a bond to be given.
The bill was taken up and passed.

Mr. Miles also reported back two bills, referred to the committee on the subject of increasing the monthly pay of non-commissioned officers and privates, with the commendation that they be laid upon the table, and the committee discharged, on the ground that the House had already passed a bill for that purpose, which was now in the Senate.

Mr. Miles also reported back joint resolutions of thanks to Gen J. Banshead Magruder and his officers and men; to Gen. W. H. Walker and his command; to Gen. Wheeler and his officers and men; all of which were adopted by the House.

Mr. Miles also reported back a bill to amend an act entitled an act to establish a general staff of the army of the Confederate States, with a recommendation from the committee that is pass.
Pending the consideration of this bid the special order was called.

Mr. Hoyston moved that the House resolve itself into Committee of the Whole for the consideration of the especial order, being a bill to provide for funding the currency.
The House went into Committee of the Whole, (Mr. Russell, of Va., in the chair) but before taking up the bill.
Mr. Lyon, of Ala., moved that the committee rise, which was agreed to, and on motion, the House resolved itself into secret session, for the consideration of the bill in question.

div3.p: The farm of Dr. J H Caperton, in Campbell co, Va, containing 140 acres, was said on the 12th instant, as $16,280.
In Knoxville, Tenn, on the 18th inst, 120 sacks of salt said at an average of $6 per bushed.

div4.p:
--The Senate met at noon. Mr. Johnson in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

Several bills, with House amendments were reported back to the Senate for its concurrence.
The amendments were concurred in.

Resolutions of Inquiry and Expediency--By Mr. Quisenborry: instructing the Committee on Confederate Relations to make some arrangement by which may be secured the necessary transportation for the salt to be distributed in the districts.
By Mr. Bates: Inquiring into, the expediency of passing a law allowing John Parson, late Sheriff of Lee county, to qualify, he being prevented by reason of the presence of the public enemy.
By Mr. Quisenborry: Concerning the expediency of refunding to Wm. M. Kelly a such of money paid by him for license which he could not use because of his connection with the army.
By Mr. Whittles Requiring all sheriffs, sergeants, and other officers holding public money in cases in which no regular settlement of accounts involving said money are required by law, to settle said accounts periodically before a Master Commissioner in the counties and corporations of this Commonwealth.

The Executive laid before the Senate a message concerning one from Governor Bonham, of South Carolina, transmitting an act passed by the Legislature of that State in relation to the guaranty of her position of the Confederate bonds.
The communications were ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee on Confederate Relations.
Mr. Thompson called up the joint resolutions in relation to the grain and tobacco interests of the State, and offered a substitute in lien thereof; which substitute was read and tabled.

Mr. Collier introduced a joint preamble and resolutions in relation to the arrest of C. J. A. Collins, a civilian citizen of Prince George, by the Confederate authorities, and calling on the Executive to demand his release for trial on the charge alleged against him; also, requesting the Governor to furnish the Senate with any correspondence he may have on the subject.
Read and laid over under the rules.

Bills Passed--A bill authorizing the County Court of Henries to establish a public fund.
A bill to repeal an ordinance of the Convention providing for a pay department of the Virginia forced.

Bill Introduced.--Mr. Collier asked leave to introduce a bill entitled "An act to prescribe prosecution and punishment of civilians for certain offences against the discipline and efficiency of the Confederate military forces."

[Mr. Douglas here announced that Gens. A. P. Hus and J. E. B Stuart were in the House of Delegates.
He asked that the Senate appoint a committee to writ upon them, and invite them to a privileged seat in the body]

The Chair appointed the committee, with Mr. Douglas chairman.
The committee retired, and soon returned with the distinguished military chieftains, who being introduced, were welcomed by the President of the Senate, both responding in some few remarks.
Half an hour after the reception the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Doggett, of the M. M. Church.

Mr. Robinson, of Richmond city, substituted a resolution, which was agreed to, that the General Assembly, having learned of the presence of Gen. J. E. B. Stuart in this city, tender to him a privileged seat upon the floor of this House.
Mr. Robinson and Mr. Crookett were appointed a committee to communicate the action of the House to Gen. Stuart.

Mr. Robinson submitted a series of resolutions, which were laid over.
The resolutions are as follows:

q.p: The General Assembly of Virginia, moved by a deep sense of the importance, at this time, of raising, above all things, an abundance of provisions and forage for the uses of our armies and the people at large; confident in our ample resources of production, as well as in the public spirit and patriotic zeal of our citizens; and fearing no deficiency or serious inconvenience beyond what at all times may occur from unfavorable seasons, except such as might result from over-confidence in these resources, or from not sufficiently adverting to the large space of our territory temporality disabled from furnishing its usual contribution to the public wants, and to other considerable portions of the Confederacy out off for the present from their usual sources of supply; but still deeming it their highest duty to guard as far as possible against even the chance of so great a calamity as the scarcity of provisions: do therefore resolve.

div4.p:
1st.
That the General Assembly, being deeply impressed with the necessity of having an abundance of provisions necessary for the sustenance of man and beast, and having an abiding confidence in the ability of Virginia to supply any deficiency, resolve that they earnestly recommend to every citizen of the State that he shall aim to increase greatly beyond his usual amount all his agricultural products of every kind whatever — his grain and his grass crops, his stock his fruits, and his garden vegetables — everything, indeed that goes to the sustenance of man and beast — before he shall apply his labor to any other object or employment whatever; that he constantly practice frugality in using his resources of food, and bear in mind always to consume first what is perishable, in order that he may husband his whole stock to the best advantages and hereby enjoin it upon and make it the special charge of every justice of the Peace throughout the State not occupied by the enemy, to visit his neighbors, and urge upon them to act promptly and effectively on this recommendation as a work of true patriotism, a sacred duty to the cause of independence and safety of the Confederate States, and as furnishing to the world the evidence of their firm and immovable determination to incur every sacrifice, and to omit no effort that may be necessary to the success of that holy cause.

2. That as many copies of the foregoing preamble and resolutions, tested by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Delegates, as they shall deem expedient, be printed in such form as they may direct for the use of the members of the General Assembly, to be by them sent to the Justices of their counties, and otherwise disseminated so as best to advance the object in view.
The resolutions were laid over.
On motion of Mr. Hunter, the bill reorganizing the State Line was taken up and passed.

Mr. Forbes submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, instructing the Committee on Courts of Justice to inquire whether, under the Constitution, the present session of the General Assembly is to be considered a continuance of the session of May last, and report to the House as soon as possible.

Mr. Hopkins, from the Committee on Extortion, reported that some days ago Joseph H. Crenshaw, Agent of the Crenshaw Manufacturing Company, and George Whitfield, President of the Franklin Paper Mill, of this city, had been summoned to appear before the committee to testify on the subject of extortionate prices; which summons had been disregarded so far as the presence of the parties was concerned, and in view of which the committee submitted the following resolution, which was agreed to:

Resolved, That Joseph H Crenghaw and George Whitfield having failed to appear before the Special Committee of this House on extortionate prices, in obedience to a summons duly served on them for that purpose, it is ordered that the Speaker of this House do issue summons to be served upon the said Joseph H Crenshaw and Geo Whitfield, to appear at the bar of this House at 12 o'clock to-morrow, and show cause why they should not be fined and imprisoned for their contempt in failing to obey the summons of its committee, said summons to be returned at 12 o'clock to-morrow.
The resolution of Mr. Pitman, providing that when this House adjourns on the 26th instant, it will adjourn sine die, was taken up and referred to the Committee on Courts.

A message was received from the Governor enclosing a communication from the Governor of South Carolina, embodying resolutions pasted by the Legislature of South Carolina, guaranteeing the bonds of the Confederate States, which were read and referred to the Committee on Finance.
Mr. Burks called up the bill authorizing fiduciaries to invest funds in their hands in certain cases, which was read a second time and referred.

Mr. Newton offered a resolution, which was agreed to, tendering to Gen. A. P. Hill, who, it was learned, was in the city, a privileged seat on the floor of the House and that the Speaker appoint a committee of two to communicate the passage of the resolution to Gen. Hill. Mr. Newton and Mr. Fry were appointed for the purpose indicated in the resolution.

On motion of Mr. Bradford the resolutions offered by himself on Saturday, relative to the authority of the Governor in commissioning officers in the State Line, were taken up for consideration, and, on motion of Mr. Hunter, were committed to the Committee on Military Affairs.
The bill for the issue of small notes was taken up, and decided in the negative.
Mr. Forbes moved a reconsideration.
Mr. Casanova moved to lay upon the table, which was agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Taylor, the House adjourned.

div3.p:
Quite a pleasant some took place in the Hall of the House of Delegates on yesterday, the occasion being the welcoming to privileged seats on the floor of that body of Major-Generals J. R. B. Stuart and A. P. Hill.
The committee appointed to notify these gentlemen of the action of the House relative to themselves appeared in the Hall, accompanied by their distinguished visitors.
Gen. Stuart first advanced to the front of the Speaker, and was received by that gentleman as follows:

q.p:
General Stuart: I have been authorized by the House of Delegates to invite you to a privileged seat in this Hall during your adjourn in the city.--I need not say to you that I communicate this honorable testimonial to your distinguished services with profound pleasure.
I have no words of studied eulogy in which to express the sentiments of gratitude and admiration you have won by your achievements.
Such words were not only in had taste, but unnecessary.
A fame like years, already historic, eclipses all eulogy.
Virginia, whose son you are, with atlast pride points to her jewels — too preed to transpot their praises is the world.
The world itself does not fail to acknowledge their worth.
The course of none of her brave sons will the follow with eye and heart more constantly and hopefully then that of yourself General, on whose brow, as the organ of Virginia sentiment.
I this day please a chaplet of honor.
I again welcome to you the seat reserved for you.

div3.p:
Gen. Stuart responded by saying that time was when the presence of military amidst legislative assemblies was intended to overawes and intimidate; but what a pleasant spectacle is presented here to-day.
Instead of fear and awe being fail, he nothing but pleasure and cordiality — Profoundly thanking the House for the honor bestowed upon him, he promised to strive to earn the gratitude expressed.

Major General Hill next came forward, and received from the Speaker a becoming welcome.
He said:

q.p:
General Hill: It is with sincere pleasure that I communicate to you the passage of a resolution inviting you to a privilege seat in this House.
It is an honor of no ordinary import.
It is no more formal reception of one who has won fame for himself and honor for his State.
No words can adequately express the sentiments of abounding gratitude this House entertains for the gallant heroes of Virginia.
It is a striking and notable characteristic of the present era that many of those who have most signally distinguished themselves in arms are youngmen — man in the flower of youth; and this House, in extending its hospitable courtesies to the chieftains of the army, is proud in recognizing you as one of them, who, though young in years have already won for yourself the fame and performed the deeds of a veteran.
I renew the expression of pleasure with which I great you as the guest of the House.

div3.p: Gen. Hill replied by thanking the House for the honor upon him. A knowledge that what little he had done in the services of his country was appreciated by the Legislature of his native State was sufficient to nerve his arm in the future, and he should endeavor to merit the appreciation so generously bestowed.
Gen. Hill then took a seat beside Gen. Stuart, and both gentleman started through a regular or deal of introduction of the hand-shaking, during which all business, of course suspended.

div3.head: A former citizen turned Traitor.
div3.p:
--A few months since the privateer Retribution sailed from a Southern port, having as Captain, Vernon Looke, a well known English Shipmaster, and as first and second officers Captain Parker, formerly of the privateer Dixic, and Charles Carroll Hicks, formerly of General Winder's police.
It was the declared intention of Capt Looke to run all his prices into Wilmington, N. C., if possible.
After being out a week he captured the brig T. Lilicott, of Boston, on board of which was placed a prize crew in charge of Hicks, with orders to make his way into Wilmington.
The Yankee papers, is giving an account of the retaking of the prize, says she was delivered up by her crew.
It appears that after Hicks act possession of the vessel he cruised around for a short time, and finally bore away to Saint Thomas, where the vessel was given up to Commodore Wilkes's squadron.

div3.head: Libby prison.
div3.p: --The following Abolition prisoners arrived at the above prison on yesterday, viz: G C Marvin, Surgeon steamer Isaac Smith, captured in Stono river, Jan. 30; H Wiggins and William Watson, co 1, 153 N Y, captured at Suffolk, Va., Feb. 10th; Israel Putnam, Geo Brown, and John Doyle, co B, 4th Delaware, captured at Mathews C H, Feb. 11.

div3.head: Novel Proceeding.
div3.p: --According to a resolution adopted by the House of Delegates yesterday Jos. H. Crenshaw and George Whitfield, citizens of Richmond, were ordered to be summoned before the bar of the House to-day, to show cause why they should not be fined and imprisoned for their contempt in refusing to obey a summons to appear and testify before the Committee on Extortion.

div3.head: Personal
div3.p:
--Gens. J. E. B. Stuart and A. P. Hill were in Richmond yesterday.
An account of their reception by the General Assembly will be found in the proceedings of that body.
Yesterday evening Gen Stuart was on the Capitol Square, witnessing the evolutions of the City Battalion, and afterwards visited Governor Letcher.

div3.head: Arrests
div3.p: --The arrests by the civil police yesterday were few, comprising a citizen too drunk to give his name, and John Jones, who was taken in custody at the Ballard House, for stealing a pair of carpet bags.

div3.head: Castle Thunder.
div3.p: --Only a half cozen deserters were reported arrived at this place yesterday.--Jacob S. Chronister a man who was waiting sentence of Court Martial, died in the Prison Hospital yesterday, of typhoid fever.

div3.head: Death of a citizens.
div3.p: --Alfred Lators, a well known citizen, formerly an Alderman or Jefferson, Ward, died at his residence, corner of 20th and franklin streets, yesterday morning.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p:
Grand Jury Presentments--Yesterday commenced the session of Judge W. H. Lyons's Court for the trial of felony cases.
The grand jury, comprising twenty-two, freeholders, assembled, and, being sworn in, chose John Purcell their foreman, and were changed by Littleton Tazewell, Commonwealth's Attorney.
They afterwards retired to their room, where several hours were consumed in examining witnesses relative to offences committed in this city.
At three o'clock P. M. the grand jury came into Court, having found indictments against the following parties for felony, viz. Jas S Tyler, Wm R. Warden, William Watkins, Bliss Vanderlip, Pat Cunningham, Geo Hoppell, Jas Kelley, Julins Desplarques, Wm Harman, Thos Tyrer, John A Whitman, James Barry, John Barry, Jno Boyd, Thos Linton, Benjamin W Carter, Andrew Rogars and A. Mason, two cases; Thomas Turpie, Adam Shafer, Samuel Blake, James M Kimore, John Phelps alias Dunbar, Robert Petterson, Jno Orrell, James A Clarke, John Boston.
Thomas T Hall Jas McQuade, John T Smith, John McGuiners, two cases; Patrick McKamee and Wm Lee. Patrick O'Neal and Pat O'Donnell.
The offences for which the above parties have been indicted for comprise every grade, from felonious swindling to deliberate and unprovoked murder.
Three or four will be tried to-day.
The Court sits at 11 o'clock.

Mayor's Court, Monday, February 16. --John Moore was brought up for having in his possession fifteen gallons of whiskey, knowing the same to have been stolen from Mason & Harman; also, sixteen, knowing they were stolen, and twelve hams of bacon, supposed to have been stolen.
The witnesses not being present, the case was laid over until Wednesday, at which time the Mayor said an examination should take piece.
Joseph Hefley, charged with getting drunk and behaving disorderly in the Theatre, was required to give security for his good behavior.
Michael Shannon, charged with getting drunk and behaving disorderly in the street, was fined $1 for getting drunk

Lawrence, slave of Joseph Hierholzer, charged with stealing eleven sheep skins and a bag of wool, the whole worth $30, belonging to his master, was convicted, and ordered 29 lashes, all he would have gotten had be been convicted before the Hustings Court.

Alice Saunders, a white female of dispidated exterior, was taken up by Lieut Kelley, of the day police, on Broad street, Sunday afternoon, and lodged in the upper station house, on the charge of wandering about the streets, having no place no stay, and being in a destitute situation.
The Mayor discharged Miss Saunders.
The case of Wm. H. Murphy, a bogus Captain and swindling substitute agent, was continued until Tuesday.

Habeas Corpus Case--Thomas Hopkins, a resident of New Kent county, was carried before Judge Lyons of the Hustings Court, yesterday, on a writ of habeas corpus shed out by his counsel, who ask for his discharge from the military prison of the Eastern District, in this city, on the ground of illegal detention.
It appears that Hopkins is a militer, and was arrested on the 21st of January by order of Brig-Gen. Henry A. Wise, on the charge of trading with the enemy, and treasonable practices generally, such as guiding them about the county during the occupation of the Peninsula by the Abolition forces.
Hopkins told one of Gen. Wise's officers that he sold meal to the Yankees at $6 per bushel.
The letter say that all the other mills in the part of New Kent infected by the Yankees were destroyed but that owned by Hopkins, which was not touched.
The hearing on the writ was contained till yesterday week.

Hustings Court.--A special session of the Aldermen's Hustings Court, Recorder James K. Caskie presiding, convened at 11 o'clock yesterday, to examine William R. Warden for the alleged offence of obtaining two hogsheads of sugar from Richard Cauthorn by false pretences.
Before any of the witnesses had been examined touching the offence for which the prisoner was arraigned he, by his counsel, waived an examination and had the case sent directly to the grand jury of Judge Lyons's Court, then in session.

Supreme Court.--The following decision was rendered by this Court on Saturday: Paul surviving partner, &c., vz Morgan and others.
Argued by William T. Joynes for the appellant, and David May for the aprelice. Decree of the Commit Court of the city of Petersburg reversed, and cause remanded for an issue to be tried before a jury.

opener.salute: To the Editor of the Dispatch:

div4.p:
My attention has just been called to an extract from a letter of a Richmond correspondent to the Mississippian, republished in your columns, referring to the late glorious exploit in Calveston harbor.
The writer of said letter relates with great preciates and fidelity some of the incidents connected with that fight which had come under my notices; but as my unknown rather assigns me a prominent position among the hornes of the battle, to which I can lay no last claim, I has on to decline the hornes which is so kindly confers upon me. While no one can bear more simple and correct testimony to the gulanery and devotion displayed by officers and men on that memorable occasion than myself, yet, confidence of the very humble share of that can justly fail to my lot, I hasten to correct the impression which would be left upon the public mind were I to leave the above letter

div3.p:
Commissioner's Sale of A Half Acre Lot, No. 28, in Duval's Addition at the corner of st. Stephen and Charity sts.--As Commissioner of the Court of Richmond appointed by a decree entered on the 12th of February, 1863, in the case of Coleman against Belt, &c, I shall proceed to sell, at public auction, on the premises on Wednesday, 25th, Feby, 1863, at 4 o'clock P. M. the above valuable half-acre Lot, fronting 144 feet on the west side of St.
Stephen street, running back on the south side of Charity street, 129 fee, and adjoining the residence of Capt. Thos C. .

Terms--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until the further order of the Court.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchase.
div3.closer:
R. H. Coleman, Com'r.
Sale conducted by Goddin & Apperson, Auctioners. fe 14

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 41, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and staled with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper with to purchase s1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: What the North is fighting for.
div3.p:
The North is fighting for self-preservation as much as for Southern subjugation, the latter of which is now chiefly desired because it involves the former.
The time when, possessed of devils, is sought to exterminate the South, in a fit of foaming, diabolic phrensy, has long since passed, and, in spite of Lincoln's proclamation, the clear, distinct object of the great mass of that nation in the further prosecution of this war is to save themselves from the overhanging avalanche of ruin which the success of the Southern cause must precipitate upon their heads.

They have learned a good deal since this war commenced.
They were going to wipe us out in sixty days! The Seventh Regiment alone, in the opinion of the magnificent James Watson Webb, would be sufficient for our subjugation!
But seven hundred regiments have not accomplished the feet.
Two years of war, and they have not even taken Richmond, which lies on the margin of our territory, and is accessible by fine, navigable stresses.
Wipe us out in sixty days! And now, after two years, they are engaged in a death struggle to keep themselves from being "wiped out" from the map of nations!

The final defeat of the North in this struggle involves.
Its total bankruptcy — commercial, financial, and political.
No lobster, divested of its hell, was ever more at the mercy of the rest of the animal erection.
It produces nothing of its own which cannot be produced elsewhere in greater perfection.
Its manufactories would tumble into ruins: for the South, their principal customer even if it could ever defile its hands again with Yankee actions, could buy cheaper and better elsewhere.
Its chips would rot at the wharves; for the South would carry its staples in its own vessels, and the monopoly of the coasting trades the fishing bounties, &c., would be dreams of the past.
The cities which have rivalled the fame of Tyre and Babylon would be forsaken for the new marts of commerce that would spring up in the Southern States.
The fountains of public revenue, mainly derived under the Union from the great staples of the South, would be dried up.--There would be neither means to pay the enormous national debt, nor to carry on the Government after the war. Repudiation, which will be the inevitable recourse of the North to pay its existing Habilities, will not improve its credit, and enable it to raise the wind hereafter.
Direct taxation heavy enough to meet its wants, would produce another revolution.
In any event, the process of disintegration successfully inaugurated would proceed with irresistible power.
The Northwest would not up for itself.
The Middle States would shake themselves clear of New England, which might humbly petition to be once more received as a British colony.
These are some of the inevitable calamities which the North is now fighting to escape, but which, in all probability, no effort she can make will be sufficient to avert.
Her doom is written, and, what is worse for her, it has been written by her own hand, and she will be her own executioner.

Without placing an invading foot upon her soil, without burning one Northern homestead, or bombarding one Northern town, the South has only to stand by and see the retribution which Providence permits these wretches, whose hands are stained with the innocent blood of our people, to inflict upon themselves.

div3.head: Summerset of John Van. Buren.
div3.p:
We published yesterday as extract from a late speech of John Van Buren, from which it may be mean that he is as much for the prosecution of the war as Lincoln or Sumner.
We were confident that not only he but all the apparent friends of the South in the Northern States would be of that way of thinking as soon as they found that the South would not agree to any farther political association with them.
They only differ from the Abolitionists in the manner of reconstructing that concern.
They are for accomplishing it by means of a treaty, while the Abolitionists are bent upon subjugating us. But the Union--the blessed Union--"the best Government the world ever saw"--Is the cry of them all. To effect its restoration they are alike ready to drown the earth in blood, provided it can be effected in no other way.

Let us cease to talk or even to think about medication, or recognition, or intervention, or disruption among the remaining States of the Union.--Nothing has a greater tendency to relax the efforts of our authorities in filling up the ranks, or to in alien the hearts of our soldiers to avoid the inevitable hardships of their situation.
It is natural that the men should relax in their discipline when they are told that whole States are breaking off from the Yankees and coming to fight their battles for them.
Just at this time it is especially important for them to know that they have their own valor alone to depend on, and to teach them anything else in to do the cause a serious injury.

div3.head: To the Rescue.
div3.p:
The great demand of the times is the rallying of the whole physical force of the Confederacy to the great points which the Yankees, in vast numbers, are now about to assault.
It is the most critical period of the whole war. Every man in the country subject to military duty should be at his post.
Every struggler should come back at once to his duty.
The Conscription law, which has been faithfully and thoroughly executed in Virginia, should be executed with equal fidelity and thoroughness in every other States.
The enrolling officers should do their duty with the most searching and unshrinking energy.
There are able bodied fighting men enough for the emergency if the Conscription law is carried out elsewhere as it has been in Virginia.
It this is not done the war may be protracted for years.
If it is done, the calls of the will everywhere be broken.

div3.head: Marrying by telegraph.
div3.p:
--On the 6th of February, a marriage ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wm. Carr, chaplain of the 4th regiment N. Y. S. V., under rather novel circumstances, the clergyman and bridegroom being in the city of Washington, and the bride in the village of Fulton Oswego county, N. Y., during the ceremony.
The bridegroom is a member of the 4th regiment, and circumstances prevented his being in Fulton to fulfill his engagement with the young lady.
By mail, the parties agreed to have the ceremony performed through the medium of the electric telegraph.
The Oswego Times says:

q.p:
The day and hour having been arranged, the parties repaired to the telegraph offices at the respective stations, the fair bride accompanied by a female friend as bridesmaid.
The gentlemanly operator at Fulton officiated as brides man. The first dispatch over the wire relating to the affair was from Washington, inquiring if the lady was present!
An answer in the affirmative was returned, and the ceremony proceeded.
Three messages were sent to Fulton and two transmitted to Washington, and the ceremony was completed.--The lass message from Washington was the declamation of the clergyman pronouncing the parties man and wife.

div3.head: Confederate financial Operations in England
div3.p:
--The London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian learns, on excellent authority, that the Confederate Government has been doing a very considerable stroke of business in England through the medium of cotton warrants.
These warrants are undertakings to deliver so much cotton of a final price — reported at 3d, to 4d, per pound — to many days after night, at any Confederate port, after a recognition of the Confederacy.
He also says it is reported that the Confederacy have even addressed proposals to the British Government for some such provisionary and speculative transactions in cotton on a large scale.

div3.head: The Kentucky Secessionists Defiant.
div3.p:
--The in the Kentucky Legislature held a at Frankfort on Thursday night last and to run W. Powell, who now a first in the United States Senate, for Governor at the August election.
General

div4.p: On the 12th inst, in this city, by the Rev. Wm. M. Christian, Mr. Thomas H. Gunn and Miss Philany L. Holdsworth, of Henrico co., Va.
Petersburg papers please copy. *
On the 15th of January, 1861, at Union Station, by the Rev. Wm. H. Christian, Mr. John W. Smith, of Baltimore city, to Miss Mary F. Flowe, of Henrico county, Virginia.
Baltimore papers please copy. *
On the 29th of January, 1863, in this city, Mr. Wm. T. Parkar, of Halifax county, to Miss Sallie F. McGHES, of Hanover county. *
On the 14th inst, of consumption, Emily Pauline Carrington, wife of W. T. Hancock, of this city.

"The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want.
Yes, though I wait through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil; for Thou art with me. Thy rod and Thy staff they comfort me." *
Raleigh papers copy.
In Chesterfield, on the 15th instant, at the residence of Mr. Benj Hatcher, Mr. Anderson Fore, in the 81st year of his age.
His funeral will take place from Mr. Hatcher's this (Tuesday) morning, at 11 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances are requested to attend. *
On Monday, the 16th instant, at half past 11 o'clock A. M., of measles, John Harvey, third son of George D. and M. A. Frayer, aged 2 years 7 months and 1 day.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully requested to attend the funeral from St. James's Church this evening, the 17th, at 3½ o'clk.
On the 16th inst, Alfred Inloes, in the 54th year of his age.

His funeral will take place from his late residence, corner of Franklin and 20th sts, this afternoon at 4 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the deceased, and of his brother, Jas A. Inloes, are invited to attend without further notice. *
In this city, on Sunday, the 15th instant, at the residence of her son, Dr. J. G. Cabell, Mrs. Agnes S. B. Cabell, relied of the late Judge; William H. Cabell, in the 81st year of her age.
Her funeral will take place this morning at 11 o'clock, from St. James's Church, where the friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend.
At 11½ o'clock P. M. on Sunday, after a short illness, Hider John W. Fussell, in the 63d year of his age.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral, at his late residence, in Henrico co, on Wednesday, at 2 o'clock P. M., without further notice. *
In Nassau, N. P., on the 30th of November, 1862, Captain Wm. P. Poythress, of this city, in the 50th year of his age.
Petersburg papers please copy. *
Departed this life at 9 o'clock on Sunday morning, at the residence of Mr. Wm. H. Wymack, in Manchester, Mrs. Nancy Smith, wife of the late Owen Smith, deceased, aged 72 years. *

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, January 15th, at Chimborazo Hospital, Sergeant-Major J. B. Martin, in the 27th year of his-age, of typhoid fever.

They have lost another brave and true soldier; another victim to this cruel war. He died from disease brought on from exposure while in the army.
This young man was a member of company E, 53d Virginia regiment, and was one of the first to respond to his country's call.
His comrades all leved him; none knew him but to love him. He has left a devoted wife and two little children, a father and mother, brother and sister.
Dear Major, he will no more administer comfort to loved hearts.
We truly sympathize with this afflicted family; but we would say weep not, dear wife; weep not, fond mother and father, God did it — it is all right.
We must and will submit, and try to meet him in Heaven. [*] From One Who Knew Him Well.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To rent, a furnished House, or three furnished Rooms in a private family.
If the latter should be obtained, the use of the kitchen is required; or an arrangement might be made for one cook to cook for both families.
A liberal price will be paid.
Address "C. P. J. War Department," at Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A reliable man, to act as a Recruiting Officer for a Partisan Ranger Company, to operate in the Valley of Virginia and borders of Maryland.
A Marylander preferred.
Address "J. M. K.," City Post-Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Immediately, four or five young Ladies to work at Dress Making.
Call at No. 28 Main street, over Bouts's Tis Store.
A good home and constant employment given.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Blacksmiths.--Wanted two No. 1 Horseshoers, for which I will pay the highest price.
Also, a good Helper, white or colored.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Samuel A. Craig.
Manchester, Feb. 15th, 1863. fe 17--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a gentleman exempt from military service, a situation in some commercial house, auction and commission preferred.
Satisfactory city references given.
Address "L. H, " Dispatch office, till 20th.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman wishes to rent a comfortably furnished Room with or without board, for himself and wife, in a respectable private family.
A liberal price will be paid.
Inquire at the office of

Enlists, 211 Main st. fe 17--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:

Written applications with reference only will be attended to.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--board in a respectable private family, within fifteen minutes walk of the Post Office, by a young gentleman.
Address "J. T. R," through the Post Office, stating terms, etc.

div3.head: Wanted — empty Bottles
div3.p: --We will pay the highest price for empty Stone Bottles,(either ale or ink bottles,) delivered in good order.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:

Apply to Dr. Furguson, Gen't Hospital No. 10, (old United States Hotel)

div3.p:
--A quick, active, intelligent Youth--one whose parents reside in the city preferred.
Apply at once to

div3.p: --Over 45 years old. For a reliable man a fair price will be paid.--Apply this morning, to

div3.head:
Attention, Marylanders!
men Wanted.
div3.p: Horses furnished and Equipments found.

I am authorized to recruit for Company D.
White's Battalion of Cavalry, C. S. A.
This company is composed almost entirely of Marylanders, and is commanded by Job Anderson, of Montgomery co., Md., I want from Ten to Twenty Recruits to complete its organization.
div3.closer:
J. G. Cannon,
Richmond House. fe 17--1t*

div3.p: Deserters from Capt J. Hatley Norton's Co. D, 18th battalion C. S. Artillery, stationed at No. 4 Battery, 1st Division, Inner Line:
R. R. Bush, Anthony Kritzer F. W. Layne, T. W. Putlum. H. B. Starling, Mike Sullivan, T. Trent Lewis Hanneman, John Hunt, John Macarthy, Mike Sullivan, (again,) James Burns, Patrick Gennings.
The usual Government reward will be paid for their apprehension and delivery in any prison or to me at camp.

div3.head: Camp 22d Va. Battalion, Fields's Brigade, A. P. Hill's Division, February 5th, 1863.
div3.p: Thirty Dollars reward.--A reward of $30 each will be paid for the arrest and the delivery to me of any one of the following named deserters:
Stepfano Couovick, an Italian, with very dark complexion, black eyes and hair, and about 5 feet 8 inches high; age, 28 years.
Augustus Kaiser, a German, with light complexion, blue eyes and light hair; about 5 feet 10 inches high, and 22 years of age.
J. R. Phelphs, hails from Lynchburg, says he

div3.head: By James M. Taylor & son, Auct's.
div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of 85 acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep Run Turnpike, at Auction.--As Administrator of John Ford, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co, and as such Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas H. Ford, who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Commissioner's Sale of Lot and Dwelling houses in the city of Richmond
div3.p:
--As Commissioner acting under a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond, pronounced on the 7th day of February, 1863, in the case of Guardian, va. Smith and others, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, beginning at 4 o'clock P. M., the property in said decree mentioned, consisting of a lot of ground, with a wooden dwelling-house and other improvements thereon, 30 feet on the East line of 2d street, between Lee and M. sts.
running back 130 feet.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until al the purchase money be paid and a conveyance directed by the Court or the purchaser at his option, may pay the whole purchase money in cash.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
H. R. Howison. Comm'r.
Sale conducted by Williamson & Co., Aucts. fe 17

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--A young negro man, named John Crisman, who came to Richmond from Williamsburg some time last spring, and who has been hired about the city until recently, has disappeared.
Fifty dollars reward will be paid by Messrs Blair & Chamberlains, on Main street, if the negro shall be delivered to them, or secured in jail in Richmond to their order.
The man is about 22 years old, black, about 5 feet 7 or 8 inches tall, and quite likely.
Mr. Parkes Slater, south side of Broad street, between 4th and 5th, can give information as to the acquaintance of the man amongst his own color, &c.

closer.signed: Robt A Bright, C. S. A.

div3.head: Twenty five Dollars reward.
div3.p: --Ranaway about the 15th of February, a black man named Miles, about 22 years old. He was purchased of W. H. Pleasants, on the 10th instant, I will pay the above reward for his delivery to Messrs Hill, Dickinson & Co.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay fifty dollars for the arrest and lodgment in a safe jail of my man George, if taken out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $20 reward if taken in those limits.
He left my house, in Manchester, on Saturday last, about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about six feet high; 21 years old brown color, and weighs about 120 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock coat, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp, to get off on the canal.
He had on a good black hat.
